The dp array is initialized with Integer.MIN_VALUE except for dp[0] which is 0. Then for each of the three possible cuts (a, b, c), they iterate through the dp array, updating the maximum count.

Hmm. Fortran has arrays, but the syntax is different. Also, Fortran uses 1-based indexing by default, but in Java it's 0-based. Need to adjust that. Let's think step by step.

In Fortran, I'll need to declare variables, set up the dp array. Let's see. The input is four integers: n, a, b, c. Then the arr array would be [a, b, c]. The dp array will be of size up to 4010, but maybe the original code uses maxn as 4010, but in Java, the dp array is of size maxn, but the loop runs up to dp.length (which is 4010). So, the Fortran code would be:

program codeforces_189_A
    implicit none
    integer :: n, a, b, c, i, j, current
    integer, parameter :: maxn = 4010
    integer :: arr(3)
    integer :: dp(0:maxn-1)

    read(*,*) n, a, b, c
    arr = [a, b, c]

    ! Initialize dp array
    dp = 0
    do i = 0, n-1
        dp(i) = -huge(0)
    end do
    dp(0) = 0

    ! Process each of the three possible cuts
    do i = 1, 3
        current = arr(i)
        do j = current, maxn-1
            dp(j) = max(dp(j), dp(j - current) + 1)
        end do
    end do

    print *, dp(n)
end program codeforces_189_A
